description.narrative: Strengthening government and community capacities for Disaster and Climate Risk Governance

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
1.1 Number of Woredas connected and IT infrastructure to support timely multi-hazard information & data sharing, exchange and dissemination between the different DRM structures and regions is done 1.2 Number of IT experts had capacity building / Training on advanced ICT skills facilitate multi hazard risk assessment and produce products 1.3 Number of ICT equipment ‘s of NDRMC maintained to ensure proper functioning of website and access to maps and indices 1.4 Number of Data on disaster damage and loss is systematically collected, collated and updated across territories and sectors including gender age disaggregated 1.5 Number of PSNP and non PSNP woredas had connectivity between NDRMC and regions / woredas and ICT facilities are put in place and functional 1.6 Number of data collector attended base early warning to ensure increased awareness and skill on information m2.1 Number of woredas where mitigation, adaptation and contingency plan is developed and mainstreamed with the woreda sectoral development plans. 2.2 Number of updated woreda level risk reduction (adaptation and mitigation) plans that manage to attract resources (local, regional, national and / or international) outside project funding indicator 2.3 Number of essential EOC facilitation equipment for effective information exchange on early warning management and documentation
4.1 Number of documents prepared on institutional capacity analysis of DRM systems at regional levels and blow and identify key-opportunities and constraints to promoting risk- informed development while covering the role of women and youth. This should highlight policy/ legal, structural resourcing constraints and opportunities 4.2 Number of quality (as per ToR; agendas) and level of activity (number of meetings; attendance; working groups; decisions etc.) inter-sectoral bodies to discuss and agree risk reduction issues and risk informed development (regional and national levels) 4.3 Number of bylaws and regulations issued to

comment.narrative: Output 1: Credible and actionable gender-disaggregated disaster risk information generated and shared 1.1 There is very little updated data on disaster related damages and losses which prevents monitoring and analysis of trends in terms of hazards, exposure and vulnerability 1.2 Inadequate aggregated multi-hazard risk assessments and maps /tools for policy and decision-makers both in highly exposed and vulnerable regions and at national level for risk-informed development plans and strategies and DRM planning 1.3 There is limited common understanding of priority on disaster risks, underlying vulnerabilities and root causes between policy makers, administrators, technical staff and concerned communities 1.4 Over half of the both PSNP and non PSNP woredas lack connectivity and inadequate ICT facilities Output 2: Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor DRM priorities and formalized DCRG roles and responsibilities in selected regions 2.1 Lack of understanding / clarity of the relationship between territorial and sector mandates and capacities Vis -a -vis DRM requirements and their prospective roles in DRM, specifically 2.2 Lack of mutually agreed common DRM priorities and targets (frameworks / plans), limited progress in mainstreaming DRM in territorial planning 2.3 Limited local government and community participation in planning exercise, lack of guidance materials and tools for local level planning (checklist, indicators etc.) Output 4: Strengthened institutional and organizational risk governance capacity to address, monitor and coordinate risk reduction 2.4 Lack of essential EOC facilitation equipment for effective information exchange on early warning 4.1 There is no institutional capacity assessment has been made to identify key opportunities for risk informed development across regions woredas and at the federal level 4.2 no inter-sectoral dialogue and coordination bodies dedicated to risk reduction and risk-informed development at national regions (ND

1.1 about 85 woredas are connected and IT infrastructure to support timely multi hazard information & data sharing, exchange and dissemination between the different DRM structures and regions 1.2 At least 7 IT experts had capacity building / training on advanced ICT skills facilitate multi-hazard risk assessment and produce products 1.3 At least 3 plotters, 3 printers, 1 photo copier machine and UPS equipment of ICT of NDRMC maintained to ensure proper functioning of website and access to maps and indices 1.4 3 joint programme review; and 2 technical staff seconded to NDRMC to support day to day programme implementation and provide advisory support 1.5 About 275 woredas both new and ongoing are connected and capable on provision of early warning information to users online. 1.6 One document on disaster Damage and loss is systematically collated and updated across territories and sector including gender and age-disaggregated 1.7 At least 175 data collector attended base early warning to ensure increased awareness and skill on information management and documentation. 2.1 about 10 woredas Mitigation adaptation and contingency plan is prepared with woreda sectoral offices in order to mainstream the plan with the woreda sectorial development plans. 2.2 Number of updated woreda level risk reduction (adaptation and mitigation) plans that manage to attract resources (local regional, national and / or international) outside project funding indicators. 2.3 at least desktop computers (15), Fax machines (5), printers 95) Printer (5) Scanner (5) Photocopy Machines (5) are procured and functional at each region. 4.1 At least comprehensive document is prepared on institutional capacity analysis of DRM systems at regional levels and below and identify key opportunities and constraints to promoting risk-informed development while covering the role of women and youth. This should highlight policy/ legal, structural and resourcing constraints and opportunities 4.2 at least two or three meetings; attendance; working groups; decisions etc.) is made inter- sectoral bodies to discuss and agree risk reduction issues and risk informed development (regional and national levels0 4.3 Number of by laws and regulations included to clarify and define structure and roles of DPPBs and various sector agencies in relations to DRM and risk reduction 4.4 Basic training package comprising key guideline, SOPs and best practices established and disseminated across DRM staff.

Output 2: Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor disaster risk reduction priorities, roles and responsibilities (Selected regions and woredas) implemented 2.1.2. IT equipment’s procured for early warning and emergency response directorate of NDRMC as per the specification Output 4: Strengthened institutional and organizational capacity to coordinate and monitor disaster and climate risk policies and actions 4.1 Conduct an institutional analysis of DRM systems ToR developed but recruitment of consultants to support activities delayed due to procurement processes. 4.5 Conduct a validation workshop on the assessment of domestic financing and resources mobilization to review and finalization of the assessment work National Domestic Resource Generation and Mobilization Strategy completed and need to be translated into local languages for sharing with the regions.

Output 1: Output 1: Credible and actionable gender-disaggregated disaster risk information generated and shared (GEN 2) _____________________________________________________________________________ Target 1.1.1 At least 60 woredas experts in hazard prone regions have been trained with multi hazard risk assessment training and accordingly obtained an esencial knowledge on risk information products and tools(reports, maps, indices, etc.) is produced and regularly used by decision makers to effectively overcome DRM. Target 1.1.2 About 50 federal and regional level government sectoral offices trained on early warning system that involve meteorological services and WHO on disease surveillance etc. Target 1.1.3 At least one Maps/Atlas is produced on specific multi-hazard risk at the woredas levels (10) to support risk-informed planning and used by decision makers. Target 1.1.4 Over 60 woredas or different DRM structures have received or connected to regular information sharing on hazards and early warning systems. Target 1.1.5 At least NDRMC data center is facilitated and installed with Antivirus and accessories to improve the quality and accessibility of disaster related information including COVID-19 pandemic/Desert locusts to all users and stakeholders. Target 1.1.6 At least 6 NDRMC ICT technical staff have advanced technical knowledge on information and communication technology including different information and communication basics, intermediate and advanced skill and able to regularly update up to date information. ________________________________________________________________________________-Output 2 Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor DRM priorities and formalized CDRG roles and responsibilities in selected regions (GEN 2) ______________________________________________________________________________- Target 2.1.1 this is a reporgrammed activty replacing the design of SOP with a project documents prepared on comprehensive guideline on post disaster recovery and rehabilitation/buidling back better in affected communities and develop an indicative guideline for resilience. Target 2.1.2 About 60 kebeles with Updated risk profiles and dissemination of data is accomplished to support to assist risk informed decision-making process at woreda level, i.e. in selected woredas (Oromia, SNNP, Somali and Gambella). Target 2.1.3 domestic financing and resources mobilization documents is translated in Amharic language and and made avaiable for further submittion to people house of federation for approval and become a legal and national document for implementation. Target 2.1.4 at least two monitoring or one evaluation is conducted and lesson is drawn for the next step. ___________________________________________________________________________________ Output 3: Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor risk reduction priorities and risk-informed national level development planning strengthened Gender marker: 1 _____________________________________________________________________________________ Target 3.1 At least one document on DRM mainstreaming instrument /check list/indicators/for national development planning and budgeting is developed and made functional Target 3.2 at least 20 or more government planners are trained at the national and subnational levels and department on risk assessment, risk informed planning and monitoring. Target 3.3 At least 30 government planner are trained one document or a mechanism is developed to design or is availed of key instruments to identify DRM expenditures in national budgeting and accounting systems. _________________________________________________________________________ Output 4: Strengthened institutional and organizational risk governance capacity to address, monitor and coordinate risk reduction (GEN 1) ________________________________________________________________________ Target 4.1 and 4.2 are reprogrammed for ICT staff salaries at the NDRMC for the period of June to December 2020. (for the accomplishment of Target 4.3 at least 20 standing committee members of parliamentarian and senior government officials attended workshop on situation specific awareness training

Results 1.1.1 The early warning and response directorate has Trained 64 experts (53 male and 11 female) from NDRMC and regions on risk identification, risk informed planning and DRM mainstreaming for three days. Results 1.1 2 the EWD has trained 50 (43 male and 7 female) participants from federal and regional level government sectoral offices on early warning system that involve metrological services and WHO on disease surveillance etc. Results 1.1.3 one maps/Atlas is produced on specific multi-hazard risk for 10 woreda in ormia and SNNPR regions to support risk-informed planning and used by decision makers Results 1.1.4 successfully accomplished woreda connectivity for woredas in Amhara, Oromia and SNNPR and in total 135 woredas have been connected to the central service to enhance early warning system and other regional level connectivity. Results1.1.5 full package of NDRMC data center is facilitated and installed with Antivirus and accessories and improved the quality and accessibility of disaster related information including COVID-19 pandemic/Desert locusts to all users and stakeholders. Results 1.1.6 from NDRMC 6 government IT employees(5male and 1 female) trained on advanced information and communication technology including different information and communication basics, intermediate and advanced skill Results 2.1.1 One documents on national guideline on post-disaster measures and building back better is developed by a consultant and now is the working documents for NDRMC in the areas of recovery and rehabilitation. Results 2.1.2 NDRMC has accomplished data collected on risk profiles from 65 kebeles and 1200 households; and development of mitigation, adaptation and contingency plans for the respective kebeles. Results 2.1.3 The resources mobilization and domestic financing documents which was is English version is translated to Amharic version and made available to NDRMC for official use. Results 2.1.4 The NDRNC has made several monitoring visit to most project areas both by DRR&R and EW&R directorates in amhara, oromia and SNNPR regions and have seen potential progresses made by the specific project and the necessary guidelines are discussed for future improvement. Results 3.1 One document is developed on sector-wide DRM mainstreaming instruments (checklists/indicator) for incorporating DRM policy and strategy into the national and sectoral development plans and budgets. Results 3.2 successfully accomplished training of 51 participants (46 male and 5 female) at the national and subnational levels and departments on risk identification, risk-informed planning and monitoring (mainstreaming of cca/drr into planning processes for resilience. 4.3 The training was given to 47 senior level government officials and technical staff for three days on risk informed planning and DRM mainstreaming and situation specific awareness raising.

Output 1: Credible and actionable gender-disaggregated disaster risk information generated and shared (GEN 2) 1.1 At least 60 hazard prone regions have been covered with multi hazard risk assessment and accordingly produced an agreed range of risk information products and tools (reports, maps, indices etc.) is produced and regularly used by decision makers to effectively overcome DRM. 1.2 About 50 federal and regional level government sectoral offices trained on early warning system that involve meteorological services and WHO on disease surveillance and etc. 1.3 over 60% of agencies or different DRM structures have received or connected to regular information sharing on hazards and early warning systems. 1.4 over 60% of agencies or different DRM structures have received or connected to regular information sharing on hazards and early warning systems. 1.5 At least one Maps/Atlas is produced on specific multi-hazard risk at the woredas levels (10) to support risk-informed planning and used by decision makers.
Output 2:- Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor DRM priorities and formalized CDRG roles and responsibilities in selected regions (GEN 2) 2.1 About 12 woreda with Updated risk profiles and dissemination of data is accomplished to support to assist risk informed decision-making process at woreda level, i.e. in selected woredas (Oromia, SNNP, Somali and Gambella) 2.2 at least 60 to 80 Trainees attained training on Disaster Risk Management and Climate change Adaptation Gender based Capacity building. 2.3 about 100 at-risk communities/HH supported with alternative livelihoods options for resilience and adaptation to climate change. Output 3: Mutually agreed gender responsive and pro-poor risk reduction priorities and risk-informed national level development planning strengthened Gender marker: 1 3.1 At least one document on DRM mainstreaming instruments (checklists/ indicators) for national development planning and budgeting is developed and made functional. 3.2 At least 20 or more government planners are trained at the national and subnational levels and departments on risk assessment, risk-informed planning and monitoring (Mainstreaming of CCA/DRR into planning processes) and implemented 3.3 at least over 60 % government staff at the federal and regional level attended ToT on Result Based M&E and System thinking in the context of DRM for Federal and Regional planning and M&E experts (estimated cost output 4: Strengthened institutional and organizational risk governance capacity to address, monitor and coordinate risk reduction (GEN 1) 4.1 at least one document on institutional analysis of DRM systems at regional levels and below and identify key opportunities and constraints to promoting risk-informed development while covering the role of women and youth. This should highlight policy/legal, structural and resourcing constraints is developed. 4.2 At least one documents on Basic training package comprising key guidelines, SOPs and best practices established and disseminated across DRM staff. 4.3 at least one higher-level government staff attended on need based and situation specific training on risk informed development training to capacitate senior decision makers technical & risk reduction.
